metadata.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Respondent No. 1

facts.text: Appellant is the proprietor of the reserved forest in Uttar Pradesh.
Respondent took lease from appellant of a plot of land at Chandan Chowki, Sonaripur Range in the North Kheri Forest Division.
Appellant granted lease to respondent for one year from 18 March 1947 at annual rent of Rs. 100/-.
Lease renewed on 10 June 1948 with effect from 18 March 1948 for one year.
Lease renewed again in 1949 for one year, expired on 18 March 1950.
After termination of lease, respondent continued in possession and agreed to abide by terms to be fixed by appellant.
Under terms fixed by appellant, respondent required to pay Rs. 1,000/- as annual rent for occupation till 15 July 1950.
Respondent remained in possession after 15 July 1950; appellant allowed occupation for three years beyond.
Respondent did not agree to any undertaking after 15 July 1950 to abide by decision of Government.
On 27 August 1951, Forest Officer wrote to respondent for discussion regarding rent for 1950-51; no evidence of discussion.
Letter dated 4 December 1951 from appellant to respondent asking to pay Rs. 3000/- for 1950-51 or reduced to Rs. 1800/- but no future lease.
Respondent continued in occupation without any agreement as to rent for 1950-51.

On 29 October 1952, Conservator of Forests sent notice offering to allow mill beyond 15 July 1950 for three years at Rs. 3000/- pa or one year at Rs. 1800/- no renewal; stated respondent mere licensee, asked to remove plant within one month and pay Rs. 6000/- damages, else suit for Rs. 5000/- pa.
Allahabad High Court judgment dated 23 October 1964 reversed trial court decree for Rs. 11,000/- and passed decree for Rs. 3,000/- with proportionate costs in favour of appellant State.
High Court found respondent continued in occupation with consent of appellant without agreement as to rent.
Lease for industrial purposes; under s.106 TPA, year to year tenancy terminable by six months notice expiring end of year; no such notice in 1952.

legal_issues.text: Whether provisions of Transfer of Property Act apply to the lease granted by the State, particularly sections 106 and 116 regarding holding over and renewal of tenancy.
Whether the lease is a Government grant under Government Grants Act excluding application of TPA.
Amount of rent payable after expiry of lease and during holding over.

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of Transfer of Property Act do not apply; respondent could not hold over under s.116 TPA; relied on Government Grants Act s.2.
Entitled to higher rent Rs.3000/- or damages Rs.5000/- pa.

respondent_arguments.text: Continued in possession with consent of appellant without agreement on rent, amounting to holding over and renewal of lease from year to year under s.116 TPA at previous rent Rs.1000/- pa.

court_reasoning.text: High Court correctly found respondent continued in occupation with consent without agreement as to rent; assent to continuance amounted to renewal of lease from 16 July 1950 as year to year tenancy under s.106 TPA, terminable by six months notice expiring end of year; no such notice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Renewed tenancy continued and was not terminated.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.116 TPA, renewal on same terms and conditions as previous lease; no agreement to pay more than Rs.1000/- pa; entitled to Rs.1000/- for three years 1950-51, 1951-52, 1952-53 i.e. Rs.3000/- total.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant not entitled to more than Rs.1000/- a year.

court_reasoning.text: Lease not a Government grant under Government Grants Act; mere fact State is lessor does not make it so; no evidence of character of land or intent as grant.
Government Grants Act s.2 requires construing grant as if TPA not passed, but does not render all TPA provisions inapplicable; s.116 operative as holding over occurred.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sections 2 and 3 give Government unfettered discretion in conditions, but TPA applies unless excluded.

holdings.text: Respondent held over within meaning of s.116 TPA; lease renewed from year to year on same terms at Rs.1000/- pa.
Government Grants Act does not exclude application of s.116 TPA to holding over.
Decree of High Court for Rs.3000/- upheld.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jnanendra Nath Nanda v. Jadu Nath Banerji
precedents_cited.relevance: Example of Government grant (Sunderbans waste lands vested in Crown).

precedents_cited.case_name: Secretary of State for India in Council v. Lal Mohan Chaudhuri
precedents_cited.relevance: Illustration of what is not a Government grant (lease of Khas Mahal lands).

precedents_cited.case_name: Lala Kishun Chand v. Sheo Dutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Government nazul land lease; holding over under s.116 TPA applies despite Government Grants Act contention.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs year to year tenancy for industrial lease and holding over renewal on same terms.

statutes_cited.name: Government Grants Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Grants construed as if TPA not passed; Government unfettered discretion in conditions; does not exclude s.116 TPA for holding over.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upholds Allahabad High Court decree awarding appellant State Rs. 3,000/- (Rs. 1,000/- per year for three years 1950-51 to 1952-53) with proportionate costs, reversing trial court decree of Rs. 11,000/-; appeal by State dismissed as respondent held over under s.116 TPA at previous rent.
outcome.relief_granted: Rs. 3,000/- to appellant State with proportionate costs
outcome.costs: Proportionate costs in favour of appellant State as per High Court decree

key_quotes.text: "the continuance by the respondent in possession of the leased premises amounted to renewal of the lease from 16 July, 1950 as a lease from year to year."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core finding on holding over under s.116 TPA.

key_quotes.text: "Section 2 of the Government Grants Act enacts that nothing in the Transfer of Property Act shall apply to any grant... but every such grant... shall be construed... as if the said Act had not been passed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains limited scope of Government Grants Act.

key_quotes.text: "The mere fact that the State is the lessor will not by itself make it a Government grant within the meaning of the Government Grants Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects State's plea on applicability to this lease.
